1.title: Agree with
1.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Used to express that you share the same opinion, view, or sentiment as someone else.

Examples:

  • I completely agree with you on that point.
  • She doesn't always agree with her boss.
  • We agree with their assessment of the situation.
  • It's difficult to agree with that conclusion without more data.
  • He agrees with me that we should postpone the launch.
  • Do you agree with the new company policy?

2.title: Apologize for
2.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Used to express regret or say you are sorry for a specific action, mistake, or behavior.

Examples:

  • You should apologize for being so late.
  • I want to apologize for my behavior last night.
  • He apologized for interrupting the meeting.
  • The company apologized for the error in the bill.
  • There is no need to apologize for asking a question.
  • She never apologizes for anything she does.

3.title: Apply for vs. Apply to
3.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verbs (Difference)

These are often confused. Apply for is used when requesting something (like a job). Apply to is used to send an application *to* a place (like a university) or to indicate relevance.

Use 1: 'Apply for' (To formally request something)

  • I am going to apply for that job.
  • Did you apply for the scholarship?
  • You need to apply for a permit.

Use 2: 'Apply to' (To send an application to an institution)

  • She applied to three different universities.
  • We applied to the same program.

Use 3: 'Apply to' (To be relevant or valid)

  • This new policy doesn't apply to our department.
  • The rules apply to everyone.

4.title: Ask for
4.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Used to request something, such as help, information, an object, or permission.

Examples:

  • Don't be afraid to ask for help if you need it.
  • She went to the bank to ask for a loan.
  • He asked for the manager, but she was in a meeting.
  • Did you ask for directions?
  • I'm asking for your opinion on this matter.
  • The client asked for a detailed report.

5.title: Away (Adverb Particle)
5.content:
Grammatical Type: Adverb Particle

'Away' is not a phrasal verb by itself. It is an adverb particle that indicates distance or removal. It combines with verbs to form many phrasal verbs.

Examples of use in Phrasal Verbs:

  • (go away) Please go away and leave me alone.
  • (put away) Put your toys away.
  • (throw away) Don't throw away that bottle; recycle it.
  • (look away) He looked away when I mentioned the error.
  • (stay away) Stay away from the edge.
  • (give away) He gave away his old clothes.

6.title: Back (Adverb Particle)
6.content:
Grammatical Type: Adverb Particle

'Back' is not a phrasal verb on its own. It is an adverb particle that indicates a return to a previous place, person, or state. It is a key component in many phrasal verbs.

Examples of use in Phrasal Verbs:

  • (call back) I'm busy, I'll call you back.
  • (give back) You must give back the book.
  • (hear back) I haven't heard back from the company yet.
  • (go back) I can't wait to go back to Italy.
  • (get back) When did you get back from your trip?
  • (pay back) I'll pay you back on Friday.

7.title: Back down
7.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To withdraw from a position, argument, or confrontation; to concede or admit defeat.

Examples:

  • He argued for a while, but he finally backed down when he saw he was wrong.
  • The union refused to back down on its demand for a pay raise.
  • She will never back down from a challenge.
  • They forced the government to back down on the new tax.
  • It's better to back down than to start a pointless fight.
  • Once he makes up his mind, he never backs down.

8.title: Back up
8.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

A very common phrasal verb with three distinct meanings: to make a copy of data, to provide support, or to move backward.

Use 1: To Copy Data

  • Remember to back up all your important files.
  • My computer crashed, but luckily I had backed up my thesis.
  • The system automatically backs up the database every night.

Use 2: To Support or Confirm

  • My colleagues will back me up in the meeting.
  • If you tell them what happened, I will back you up.
  • Do you have any evidence to back up your claims?

Use 3: To Move Backward (Literal)

  • You need to back up the car a little more.
  • Can you back up? You're blocking the exit.
  • The truck backed up slowly.

9.title: Believe in
9.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To have faith in the existence of something, or to trust that someone or something is good, valuable, or capable.

Use 1: To Trust in someone's ability or value

  • You have to believe in yourself if you want to succeed.
  • Her parents always believed in her, even when she failed.
  • The team believes in their coach's strategy.
  • We believe in this project.

Use 2: To have faith in an idea or existence

  • Do you believe in ghosts?
  • We believe in the importance of free speech.
  • He believes in second chances.

10.title: Break down
10.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

A versatile phrasal verb with several meanings: to stop functioning, to lose emotional control, or to analyze something in detail.

Use 1: To Stop Functioning (Mechanical)

  • My car broke down on the way to work this morning.
  • The main server broke down, causing a network outage.
  • Production stopped because the assembly line broke down.

Use 2: To Lose Emotional Control

  • She broke down in tears when she heard the bad news.
  • The intense questioning finally made the suspect break down and confess.
  • It's okay to break down; you've been under a lot of stress.

Use 3: To Analyze or Divide into Parts

  • Let's break down this complex project into smaller, manageable tasks.
  • Can you break down the costs for me?
  • The report breaks down the sales data by region.

11.title: Break up
11.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

A common phrasal verb with multiple meanings, including ending a relationship, dispersing a gathering, or losing communication signal.

Use 1: To End a Relationship

  • They decided to break up after three years together.
  • She broke up with him last month.
  • Hearing about their break-up (noun) surprised everyone.

Use 2: To Disperse a Gathering

  • The police arrived and broke up the party.
  • The teacher had to break up a fight between two students.
  • The meeting broke up at 11 PM.

Use 3: To Lose Signal (Communication)

  • Sorry, I can't hear you. You're breaking up.
  • We were talking, but the call broke up.

Use 4: To Break into Pieces

  • The ship broke up on the rocks.
  • The cookie just broke up in my hand.

12.title: Bring about
12.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

A formal phrasal verb meaning to cause something to happen, often a significant change or event.

Examples:

  • The fire in the kitchen was brought about by a faulty wire.
  • The new manager brought about many positive changes in the company.
  • The new policy will bring about a lot of resistance.
  • Social media has brought about a revolution in communication.
  • We are hoping the negotiations will bring about a peaceful resolution.
  • What brought about this sudden change in his behavior?

13.title: Bring forward
13.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To move a planned event or meeting to an earlier date or time.

Examples:

  • The client asked if we can bring forward the meeting to this Wednesday.
  • Due to the weather, they decided to bring forward the festival by one day.
  • Can we bring forward the deadline to Monday?
  • The meeting has been brought forward from 3 PM to 1 PM.
  • Let's bring forward our discussion on the budget.
  • The release date was brought forward to compete with a rival product.

14.title: Bring up
14.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has three common uses: to mention a topic, to raise a child, or (informally) to vomit.

Use 1: To Mention a Topic

  • Don't bring up politics at dinner if you want a peaceful evening.
  • I hate to bring this up, but you still owe me $50.
  • She brought up an interesting point during the presentation.

Use 2: To Raise a Child

  • She was brought up by her grandparents in the countryside.
  • They brought up their children to be polite and respectful.
  • It is expensive to bring up a child in the city.

Use 3: To Vomit (Informal)

  • He ate some bad fish and brought up his entire dinner.
  • I felt like I was going to bring up my lunch.

15.title: Build up
15.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To increase or accumulate gradually over time, such as strength, tension, or a physical quantity. It can also be used as a noun ('build-up').

Examples:

  • You need to build up your strength slowly after the surgery.
  • The tension in the room was building up as we waited.
  • He has built up a very successful business over the years.
  • Dirt can build up in the filter if you don't clean it.
  • The media built up the event, but it was disappointing.
  • There was a build-up (noun) of traffic near the stadium.

16.title: Burn down
16.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To be completely destroyed by fire, usually referring to a building.

Examples:

  • The old warehouse burned down last night.
  • The fire was so intense it burned down the entire building.
  • They watched helplessly as their house burned down.
  • If the forest is too dry, it could easily burn down.
  • The restaurant burned down, and they had to rebuild it.
  • The firefighters arrived too late to stop the factory from burning down.

17.title: Buy-in (Noun)
17.content:
Grammatical Type: Noun

Refers to the agreement, acceptance, or support for a plan, idea, or decision from a person or group. This is the *result* you get from the phrasal verb 'buy into'.

Examples:

  • Before we proceed, we need to get buy-in from the stakeholders.
  • The project failed because there was no buy-in from the management.
  • His first task is to secure buy-in from the team.
  • Gaining employee buy-in is crucial for this new policy.
  • Without full buy-in, the plan will not work.
  • How do we achieve buy-in on this proposal?

18.title: Buy into
18.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To believe in or fully accept an idea, plan, or philosophy, especially to the point of giving it your support. This is the *action* of getting 'buy-in'.

Examples:

  • His presentation helped the team buy into the new workflow.
  • I don't buy into the idea that we need to work weekends to be successful.
  • She never really bought into the company's 'family' culture.
  • It's hard to buy into his excuses anymore.
  • The employees are starting to buy into the new vision for the company.
  • They won't buy into the plan unless they see the benefits.

19.title: Call off
19.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To cancel a planned event, such as a meeting, party, or game.

Examples:

  • They had to call off the wedding at the last minute.
  • The manager called off the meeting because no one was prepared.
  • If it rains, we will have to call off the picnic.
  • The search was called off due to bad weather.
  • He called off the attack when he saw the white flag.
  • Is it too late to call off the party?

20.title: Calm down
20.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To become, or help someone become, relaxed, less angry, or less upset.

Examples:

  • Take a deep breath and try to calm down.
  • He was very angry, and it took a long time to calm him down.
  • Things will seem better after you've calmed down.
  • Please calm down and tell me what happened.
  • I tried to calm the crying child down.
  • The crowd calmed down after the police arrived.

21.title: Care about
21.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To feel that something or someone is important and worth being concerned about.

Examples:

  • Itâ€™s obvious that she really cares about her students.
  • I don't care about money; I just want to be happy.
  • He pretends not to care about what people think of him.
  • Why should I care about your problems?
  • The only thing he cares about is his career.
  • If you cared about me, you wouldn't do that.

22.title: Care for
22.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to look after someone (like a child or patient), or (formally, often in negative sentences) to not like something.

Use 1: To Look After / Provide for

  • He is caring for his elderly mother at home.
  • Who will care for your dog while you're on vacation?
  • The nurses cared for the patients.
  • He has a large family to care for.

Use 2: To Like or Want (Formal)

  • I don't really care for spicy food.
  • (Polite offer) Would you care for some tea?
  • He didn't care for the movie very much.

23.title: Carry on
23.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to continue doing something, or (common in UK English) to behave in an excited or uncontrolled way.

Use 1: To Continue

  • Please carry on with your work while I take this call.
  • We must carry on regardless of the challenges.
  • I'm sorry for the interruption, carry on.
  • They decided to carry on with the plan.

Use 2: To Behave Badly or Childishly (UK)

  • Stop carrying on! It's just a small cut.
  • He was carrying on and shouting at the referee.
  • There's no need to carry on like that.

24.title: Catch on
24.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to understand or realize something, or to become popular or fashionable.

Use 1: To Understand

  • He speaks so fast it's hard to catch on to what he's saying.
  • She explained the joke, but I was slow to catch on.
  • He finally caught on to the fact that they were teasing him.

Use 2: To Become Popular

  • The new fashion trend quickly caught on with teenagers.
  • I wonder if this new app will ever catch on.
  • That song caught on last summer and was played everywhere.

25.title: Catch up (Social)
25.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To talk to someone you haven't seen in a while and find out what they have been doing. It's often used interchangeably with 'catch up with'.

Examples:

  • Let's get coffee this weekend; we need to catch up.
  • It was great to catch up with old friends at the reunion.
  • I haven't seen you in ages! We must catch up soon.
  • I'm calling my sister to catch up on all the family news.
  • We spent the whole evening just catching up.
  • When do you have time to catch up?

26.title: Catch up on
26.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To do something that you did not have time to do earlier; to bring yourself up to date with work, news, or a task.

Examples:

  • I missed a week of classes, so I have a lot of work to catch up on.
  • I use my commute to catch up on my reading.
  • She spent the weekend catching up on her sleep.
  • He needs to catch up on his emails after his vacation.
  • I'm trying to catch up on the latest episodes of my favorite show.
  • What's the best way to catch up on the news I missed?

27.title: Catch up with
27.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to reach someone who is ahead of you, or to talk to someone you haven't seen in a while (synonym of 'catch up').

Use 1: To Talk and Update (Social)

  • Let's have coffee soon; I'd love to catch up with you.
  • It was so good to catch up with him after all these years.
  • I need to catch up with my boss about the project.

Use 2: To Reach Someone Ahead (Physical)

  • She was walking so fast, I had to run to catch up with her.
  • You go ahead; I'll catch up with you later.
  • After being sick, he had to work hard to catch up with the rest of the class.

28.title: Check in
28.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to register your arrival (at a hotel, airport), or to contact someone to report your status or see how they are.

Use 1: To Register Arrival

  • We need to check in at the hotel before 3 PM.
  • What time do we have to check in for our flight?
  • Please check in at the front desk when you arrive.
  • Have you checked in online?

Use 2: To Report or Contact Someone

  • Please check in when you get to the hotel so we know you're safe.
  • I need to check in with my boss before I leave for the day.
  • She checks in with her parents every Sunday.

29.title: Check out
29.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Multiple uses: to leave a hotel, to examine something, or to borrow something (like a library book).

Use 1: To Look At or Examine (Informal)

  • You should check out that new restaurant downtown.
  • Hey, check out this cool website I found.
  • I'm going to check out the new art exhibit this weekend.

Use 2: To Leave and Pay (Hotel)

  • We have to check out of the hotel by 11 AM.
  • What time is check-out? (noun)
  • Please return your key card when you check out.

Use 3: To Borrow (Library)

  • I'm going to check out these books from the library.
  • How many DVDs can I check out at one time?

30.title: Cheer up
30.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To become happier, or to make someone feel happier.

Examples:

  • Here's a joke to help you cheer up.
  • She was feeling sad, so her friends took her out to cheer her up.
  • Cheer up! Things will get better.
  • He bought her flowers to cheer her up.
  • I tried to cheer up the team after they lost the game.
  • He started to cheer up when he heard the good news.

31.title: Circle back
31.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

A business expression meaning to return to a topic, person, or discussion at a later time.

Examples:

  • That's a good point. Let's circle back to it after we discuss the budget.
  • I don't have the answer right now, but I will circle back with you tomorrow.
  • We need to circle back to the original plan.
  • Can we circle back to this issue in our next meeting?
  • I'll circle back with my manager and let you know.
  • Let's finish this point and then circle back to your question.

32.title: Clean up
32.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To make a place tidy by removing dirt, waste, or unwanted items.

Examples:

  • We need to clean up the kitchen after dinner.
  • It took hours to clean up the mess after the party.
  • The city is trying to clean up the park.
  • You should clean up your room; it's a disaster.
  • The company had to clean up a chemical spill.
  • Please clean up after your dog.

33.title: Clear up
33.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has three main uses: for weather to improve, to resolve a misunderstanding, or for a medical issue (like a rash or infection) to heal.

Use 1: To Resolve Confusion

  • We need to clear up this misunderstanding before it causes problems.
  • Thank you for clearing up that point; I understand now.
  • Can you clear up a few details for me?

Use 2: For Weather to Improve

  • The weather forecast says it will clear up later this afternoon.
  • I hope the sky clears up so we can go to the beach.
  • It was raining, but it cleared up around noon.

Use 3: To Heal or Disappear (Medical)

  • This cream should help your rash clear up.
  • My cold finally cleared up last week.
  • The infection cleared up after taking antibiotics.

34.title: Close down
34.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To stop operating permanently, usually referring to a business, shop, or factory.

Examples:

  • Many small shops have had to close down recently.
  • The factory closed down and moved its operations overseas.
  • If they can't make a profit, they will have to close down.
  • The old library closed down last year.
  • They are closing down that branch of the bank.
  • The pandemic forced many restaurants to close down.

35.title: Come across
35.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to find something or someone by chance, or to seem to be a certain type of person (to give an impression).

Use 1: To Find by Chance

  • I came across this old photo album while cleaning the attic.
  • She came across a rare book in a small shop.
  • If you come across my keys, please let me know.

Use 2: To Give an Impression

  • She comes across as a very confident person.
  • He came across as rude in the meeting, but he was just stressed.
  • How do I come across in interviews?

36.title: Come around
36.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To change your opinion or decision because someone has persuaded you. Can also mean to regain consciousness.

Use 1: To Change Your Opinion

  • She finally came around and agreed to sell the house.
  • He didn't like the idea at first, but he eventually came around.
  • I think he'll come around to our way of thinking.
  • My parents were worried, but they came around.

Use 2: To Regain Consciousness

  • He fainted, but he came around after a few seconds.
  • She was unconscious for a minute before she came around.

37.title: Come back
37.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To return to a place, or to return to a state of being (like a memory or fashion trend).

Examples:

  • Please come back soon; we miss you.
  • He left the company but came back a year later.
  • The memory of that day often comes back to me.
  • That fashion style from the 90s is coming back.
  • What time are you coming back from your trip?
  • I'll come back to this topic later in the presentation.

38.title: Come up
38.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has three main uses: for an unexpected problem to arise, for a topic to be mentioned, or to move upwards.

Use 1: When Something Unexpected Happens

  • I'm sorry I have to cancel, something important came up.
  • I have to work late; an urgent issue came up.
  • He always has an excuse when a problem comes up.

Use 2: When a Topic is Raised

  • Your name came up in conversation yesterday.
  • The issue of salaries is likely to come up at the meeting.
  • Did my proposal come up during your discussion?

Use 3: To Move Upward (Literal)

  • The sun came up over the horizon.
  • A message came up on the screen.

39.title: Come up with
39.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To think of or create something, such as an idea, a plan, a solution, or an excuse.

Examples:

  • She came up with a great idea for the new project.
  • We need to come up with a new strategy before the next quarter.
  • How did you come up with that name for your dog?
  • He came up with a clever excuse for being late.
  • The team came up with a workaround for the bug.
  • It's hard to come up with original ideas all the time.

40.title: Consist of
40.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To be composed or made up of certain parts or elements.

Examples:

  • A healthy smoothie typically consists of fruits, vegetables, and some liquid.
  • The exam will consist of a written test and a practical demonstration.
  • The committee consists of five members.
  • The training consists of three main modules.
  • Their report consists of several pages of data.
  • A full-time job consists of about 40 hours per week.

41.title: Count on
41.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To rely on or trust someone to do something or to be there for you.

Examples:

  • You can always count on me if you need help.
  • I'm counting on you to finish this report by Friday.
  • She's a great colleague; you can count on her.
  • We are counting on good weather for the outdoor event.
  • Don't count on the bus being on time.
  • He knew he could count on his friends for support.

42.title: Crack down on
42.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To take strong, severe measures to stop or punish an illegal or undesirable activity.

Examples:

  • The government is trying to crack down on illegal immigration.
  • The school decided to crack down on students who are late.
  • Police are cracking down on drunk driving this holiday weekend.
  • The new manager is cracking down on employees who take long breaks.
  • We need to crack down on wasteful spending.
  • The city is cracking down on illegal parking.

43.title: Cut down on
43.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To reduce the amount or quantity of something, especially something you eat, drink, or use.

Examples:

  • I'm trying to cut down on sugar.
  • The doctor told him to cut down on salt and fat.
  • We need to cut down on our household expenses.
  • She's cut down on the number of hours she works.
  • Cutting down on social media has improved my focus.
  • I'm trying to cut down on coffee; I only drink one cup a day now.

44.title: Cut off
44.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has multiple uses: to stop the supply of something, to interrupt someone, or to remove something by cutting.

Use 1: To Stop a Supply (Electricity, Money, etc.)

  • The power was cut off during the storm.
  • His parents cut him off after he dropped out of college.
  • The town was cut off from the rest of the world by the flood.

Use 2: To Interrupt Speaking

  • The argument started because he cut me off in the middle of my sentence.
  • She kept cutting me off while I was trying to explain.
  • The connection was bad, and we got cut off.

Use 3: To Remove by Cutting

  • He cut off a branch from the tree.
  • She cut off the price tag from the shirt.

45.title: Deal with
45.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To take the necessary action to manage or solve a problem, situation, or person. It can also mean to be about a certain subject.

Use 1: To Manage or Solve

  • The customer support team is trained to deal with difficult clients.
  • I have to deal with a lot of emails every morning.
  • How do you deal with stress?
  • We will deal with that problem when it happens.

Use 2: To be About (Subject)

  • The book deals with the history of the Roman Empire.
  • Her presentation deals with climate change.

46.title: Depend on
46.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To rely on someone for support, or for a situation to be determined or influenced by something else.

Use 1: To Be Determined By

  • Our trip depends on the weather.
  • The whole presentation depends on the first slide being correct.
  • A: 'Are you going to the party?' B: 'It depends on whether I finish my work.'

Use 2: To Rely On / Trust

  • Children depend on their parents for food and shelter.
  • You can't depend on him; he's always late.
  • The success of this project depends on everyone working together.

47.title: Draw up
47.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To prepare and write a formal or official document, such as a contract, plan, or agreement.

Examples:

  • The legal team will draw up the contract for the new partnership.
  • The two sides will meet to draw up a peace agreement.
  • We need to draw up a new business plan for next year.
  • The architect drew up the blueprints for the house.
  • They drew up a list of potential candidates.
  • The committee was tasked with drawing up new guidelines.

48.title: Drill down
48.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

A business or data term meaning to examine something in greater detail or at a deeper level.

Examples:

  • Let's drill down into the user engagement data from last week.
  • The report gives a good overview, but we need to drill down to find the root cause.
  • If you click on a state, you can drill down to see data by city.
  • We have to drill down and analyze the feedback from each customer segment.
  • The manager asked us to drill down into the quarterly expenses.
  • This meeting is for drilling down on the project's requirements.

49.title: Drop in
49.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To make a short, informal, and often unannounced visit to see someone.

Examples:

  • Feel free to drop in anytime you're in the neighborhood.
  • I'm so glad you dropped in!
  • My sister dropped in for a coffee on her way home.
  • I might drop in on my grandparents this weekend.
  • The boss sometimes drops in to see how we're doing.
  • It's not a formal party; just drop in when you can.

50.title: Drop off
50.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has three main uses: to deliver someone/something, to decrease, or (informally) to fall asleep.

Use 1: To Deliver or Transport

  • Can you drop me off at the airport tomorrow morning?
  • I need to drop off these books at the library.
  • The bus drops off passengers right at the terminal.
  • She dropped off the package on her way to work.

Use 2: To Decrease or Decline

  • Sales dropped off sharply after the holiday season.
  • Student engagement tends to drop off near the end of the semester.
  • The internet connection drops off in the back rooms.

Use 3: To Fall Asleep (Informal)

  • I dropped off on the sofa while watching the movie.
  • He was so tired he dropped off during the meeting.
  • She dropped off to sleep around midnight.

51.title: Drop out
51.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To quit or stop participating in something, such as a school, university, course, or race, before it is finished.

Examples:

  • He decided to drop out of college and start his own business.
  • She dropped out of the race after injuring her leg.
  • A lot of students drop out after the first year.
  • If you drop out now, you won't get your certificate.
  • He was a dropout (noun) who later became a millionaire.
  • Why did he drop out of the competition?

52.title: Eat out
52.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To have a meal at a restaurant instead of at home.

Examples:

  • We don't cook much on Fridays; we usually eat out.
  • It's a special occasion, let's eat out at that fancy Italian place.
  • I'm too tired to cook tonight. Do you want to eat out?
  • Eating out can be expensive if you do it too often.
  • They eat out at least once a week.
  • Where should we eat out tonight?

53.title: End up
53.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To finally be in a particular place or situation, often unexpectedly or as the result of a long process.

Examples:

  • We took a wrong turn and ended up in a completely different town.
  • He never wanted to be a manager, but that's how he ended up.
  • If you keep spending money like that, you'll end up with no savings.
  • She studied law but ended up working as a journalist.
  • We were supposed to go to the beach, but we ended up going to the movies because of the rain.
  • He ended up marrying his high school sweetheart.

54.title: Fall asleep
54.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (or Collocation)

To begin sleeping, often unintentionally. It describes the transition from being awake to being asleep.

Examples:

  • I fell asleep on the sofa while watching a movie.
  • He was so tired that he fell asleep as soon as his head hit the pillow.
  • The meeting was so boring that I almost fell asleep.
  • She falls asleep very quickly after a long day.
  • Don't fall asleep while driving!
  • The baby finally fell asleep after an hour of crying.

55.title: Feel like
55.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to have a desire for something (followed by gerund -ing or a noun), or to feel as if something is true.

Use 1: To Want or Desire

  • I feel like eating pizza tonight.
  • I don't feel like going out; I'd rather stay home.
  • Do you feel like a walk?
  • She feels like watching a comedy.

Use 2: To Have a Sensation or Impression

  • I feel like I've known you for years.
  • It feels like it's going to rain.
  • This feels like real silk.

56.title: Figure out
56.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To understand or solve something by thinking. It can apply to a problem, a person's behavior, or how to do something.

Examples:

  • I can't figure out how to solve this math problem.
  • We need to figure out a way to save money.
  • I finally figured out what was wrong with the code.
  • She's very unpredictable; I can't figure her out.
  • Let's try to figure out how to assemble this furniture.
  • Don't worry, we'll figure something out.

57.title: Fill in
57.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has three common uses: to complete a form (UK English), to substitute for someone, or to provide someone with details.

Use 1: To Complete a Form (Mainly UK)

  • Please fill in this form with your name and address.
  • You need to fill in all the blank spaces.
  • (Note: 'fill out' is more common in US English for this).

Use 2: To Substitute for Someone ('fill in for')

  • Could you fill in for me while I'm on vacation?
  • Our regular teacher is sick, so a substitute is filling in.

Use 3: To Provide Details ('fill someone in')

  • I missed the meeting. Can you fill me in?
  • Let me fill you in on what happened.

58.title: Fill out
58.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to complete a form (common in US English), or to become larger or fuller (e.g., a person's body).

Use 1: To Complete a Form (Mainly US)

  • Please fill out this application form and return it by Friday.
  • It took me an hour to fill out all the paperwork.
  • You must fill out a customs declaration.

Use 2: To Become Fuller or Larger

  • He was very thin as a teenager, but he filled out in his twenties.
  • The new trees will fill out in a few years and provide more shade.

59.title: Find out
59.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To discover a piece of information, or to discover that someone has been deceptive.

Use 1: To Discover Information

  • I need to find out what time the movie starts.
  • She was shocked to find out that she had failed the exam.
  • Can you please find out who is in charge?
  • We will find out the results tomorrow.

Use 2: To Discover Deception ('find someone out')

  • He had been lying for months, but his boss finally found him out.
  • She was afraid her parents would find her out.

60.title: Focus on
60.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To concentrate or give all your attention to a particular person, task, or subject.

Examples:

  • You need to focus on your studies if you want to pass the exam.
  • Let's focus on the main problem, not the minor details.
  • In this meeting, I want to focus on our quarterly budget.
  • She focused on her breathing to stay calm.
  • The company is focusing on improving customer service.
  • It's hard to focus on work when it's so noisy.

61.title: Follow up
61.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (or Noun 'follow-up')

To take further action connected with something that happened earlier; to continue communication or check on progress.

Examples:

  • I will follow up with an email summarizing the action items.
  • Thank you for the meeting; I will follow up on those questions.
  • The doctor wants to follow up with me in two weeks.
  • It's important to follow up on sales leads.
  • This email is a follow-up (noun) to our conversation.
  • Did you ever follow up on that complaint?

62.title: Freak out
62.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

An informal verb meaning to become, or cause someone to become, extremely scared, angry, or excited, often losing control.

Examples:

  • Don't freak out, but I think I lost the car keys.
  • She freaked out when she saw the spider.
  • He's going to freak out when he sees the mess we made.
  • I'm freaking out about my exam tomorrow.
  • The loud noise freaked out the cat.
  • My parents freaked out when I told them I was dropping out.

63.title: Get across
63.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To successfully communicate or make an idea or feeling understood by others.

Examples:

  • She's an excellent speaker who can easily get across her ideas.
  • I tried to explain the problem, but I couldn't get across how serious it was.
  • What is the main point you are trying to get across?
  • He used a simple analogy to get his point across.
  • It's difficult to get across complex emotions in a text message.
  • We need a better way to get this message across to the public.

64.title: Get along
64.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To have a friendly, harmonious relationship with someone. This form is often used without a direct object.

Examples:

  • I get along really well with my new colleagues.
  • Despite their differences, the two leaders seem to get along.
  • We're not close friends, but we get along.
  • It's amazing how well the cat and dog get along.
  • They used to fight, but they get along fine now.
  • I'm an easygoing person; I can get along with almost anyone.

65.title: Get along with
65.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To have a friendly, harmonious relationship *with* a specific person. This is the most common form, used with a direct object.

Examples:

  • Do you get along with your new roommate?
  • He doesn't get along with his sister.
  • I've always gotten along with my boss.
  • It's important to get along with your neighbors.
  • I find him very easy to get along with.
  • She's worried her son won't get along with the other kids.

66.title: Get around
66.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to bypass or avoid a problem/rule, or to travel from place to place within an area.

Use 1: To Bypass or Avoid

  • We need to find a way to get around this problem.
  • The company is trying to get around the new regulations.
  • There's no getting around the fact that we made a mistake.

Use 2: To Travel or Move

  • It's easy to get around the city on foot.
  • How do you get around without a car?
  • The subway is the fastest way to get around London.

67.title: Get away
67.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to escape from a person or place, or to take a vacation.

Use 1: To Escape

  • The thief managed to get away before the police arrived.
  • I just want to get away from the noise and crowds.
  • The dog got away from its owner.

Use 2: To Take a Vacation

  • I need to get away from the city for a few days.
  • We're hoping to get away to the beach this summer.
  • This weekend is a perfect chance to get away.

68.title: Get away with
68.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To do something wrong or illegal and not be caught or punished for it.

Examples:

  • He cheated on the test and thought he could get away with it.
  • You can't just break the rules and expect to get away with it.
  • His rude behavior is unacceptable; don't let him get away with it.
  • She got away with paying a very small fine.
  • No one ever gets away with lying to the boss.
  • How does he get away with being late every day?

69.title: Get by
69.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To manage to live or survive with just enough money, resources, or knowledge.

Examples:

  • My Spanish isn't perfect, but I know enough to get by.
  • It's hard to get by on such a low salary.
  • We don't have much money, but we get by.
  • You don't need a new computer; your old one will get by for now.
  • How does she get by with four children and no job?
  • I can get by with just a few hours of sleep.

70.title: Get in
70.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has multiple uses: to arrive (trains, planes), to enter a place, or to submit or include something.

Use 1: To Arrive

  • What time does the train from London get in?
  • My flight got in late last night.
  • We should be home by the time they get in.

Use 2: To Enter (a car, a building)

  • Hurry up and get in the car!
  • How did the thief get in?
  • He forgot his keys and couldn't get in the house.

Use 3: To Submit or Include

  • It's important to get in all the ingredients before you start cooking.
  • Did you get your application in on time?

71.title: Get on with
71.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to continue doing something (especially after an interruption), or to have a good relationship with someone (synonym of 'get along with').

Use 1: To Continue a Task

  • I need to stop procrastinating and get on with my work.
  • After the argument, they tried to get on with their lives.
  • The meeting is over; let's get on with the rest of the day.

Use 2: To Have a Good Relationship (Mainly UK)

  • How do you get on with your new boss?
  • She gets on with everyone.
  • I don't really get on with my brother-in-law.

72.title: Get out
72.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To leave or escape from a place. It can be a command or a description.

Examples:

  • The building is on fire! Everyone needs to get out now!
  • (As a command) Get out of my room!
  • We need to get out of the house and get some fresh air.
  • The prisoner planned his escape to get out.
  • I'm so busy, I rarely get out these days.
  • How did the dog get out of the yard?

73.title: Get over
73.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to recover from an illness or a negative emotional experience (like a breakup), or to physically climb over something.

Use 1: To Recover (Emotionally or Physically)

  • It took him a long time to get over the death of his dog.
  • She's still getting over the flu.
  • He can't get over his breakup.
  • You'll get over it; these things take time.

Use 2: To Physically Climb Over

  • The thief had to get over a high fence to escape.
  • We couldn't get over the fallen tree, so we turned back.

74.title: Get rid of
74.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To discard, eliminate, or free yourself from something or someone unwanted.

Examples:

  • I need to get rid of all these old clothes.
  • We finally got rid of the mice in the attic.
  • I can't get rid of this headache.
  • The company is trying to get rid of its old inventory.
  • He's trying to get rid of his bad habits.
  • Are you sure you want to get rid of that painting?

75.title: Get through
75.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has three main uses: to successfully complete a difficult task, to make contact by phone, or to use up a supply of something.

Use 1: To Complete a Difficult Task or Period

  • The final exam was so difficult, I didn't think I would get through it.
  • I just need to get through this week, and then I'm on vacation.
  • She's having a hard time, but her friends are helping her get through it.

Use 2: To Make Contact (Phone)

  • I tried calling you, but I couldn't get through. The line was busy.
  • Did you manage to get through to customer service?

Use 3: To Use Up a Supply

  • We get through a lot of milk in this house.
  • How do you get through so much work in one day?

76.title: Give in
76.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To finally agree to something that you were resisting; to surrender or stop fighting.

Examples:

  • The kids kept asking for ice cream, and I finally gave in.
  • He argued for an hour, but gave in when he saw he was wrong.
  • The company refused to give in to the workers' demands.
  • Don't give in to temptation.
  • After weeks of negotiation, the other side gave in.
  • I didn't want to go, but her persistence made me give in.

77.title: Give off
77.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To produce and emit something, such as a smell, heat, light, or a specific impression (vibe).

Examples:

  • The flowers give off a beautiful scent.
  • The old engine gives off a lot of smoke.
  • That radiator isn't giving off much heat.
  • The rotten food gave off a horrible smell.
  • She gives off a very confident vibe.
  • The screen gives off a blue light that can affect your sleep.

78.title: Give out
78.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to distribute or hand something to many people, or for a piece of equipment to stop working.

Use 1: To Distribute

  • They were giving out free samples at the store.
  • The teacher gave out the exam papers.
  • He gave out flyers for his new business.

Use 2: To Stop Working (Equipment or Body Part)

  • My old laptop finally gave out after ten years.
  • His legs gave out near the end of the marathon.
  • The printer gave out right in the middle of a big job.

79.title: Give up
79.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To quit or stop doing something, such as a habit (smoking), a hobby, or a difficult task. It means to surrender or stop trying.

Examples:

  • He gave up smoking five years ago.
  • The puzzle was too hard, so I gave up.
  • Don't give up! You almost have it.
  • She gave up her job to travel the world.
  • They gave up trying to fix the old car.
  • The team gave up after the other team scored again.

80.title: Give up on
80.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To stop believing in someone or something; to lose hope that someone or something will improve or succeed.

Examples:

  • Don't give up on your dreams, no matter how hard it gets.
  • His teachers gave up on him, but he proved them wrong.
  • I'm giving up on trying to get him to help.
  • The team never gave up on winning the game.
  • She gave up on the project.
  • It's easy to give up on people.

81.title: Go ahead
81.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to give permission to do something, or to proceed or start doing something.

Use 1: To Give Permission

  • 'May I start the presentation?' 'Yes, go ahead.'
  • 'Can I use your phone?' 'Sure, go ahead.'
  • He asked if he could leave, and the boss told him to go ahead.

Use 2: To Proceed or Start

  • We decided to go ahead with the plan despite the risks.
  • The project will go ahead as scheduled.
  • You start walking, and I'll go ahead to get the car.

82.title: Go after
82.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To pursue or chase someone or something in an attempt to catch them, or to try to achieve or get something (like a job or a goal).

Use 1: To Chase or Pursue

  • The police car is going after the speeding vehicle.
  • The dog went after the cat.
  • He went after the thief who stole his bag.

Use 2: To Try to Achieve

  • She's going after the CEO position.
  • If you want that promotion, you have to go after it.
  • He's going after his dream of becoming a pilot.

83.title: Go back / Go back on
83.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

'Go back' means to return to a place. 'Go back on' means to break a promise or agreement.

Use 1: 'Go back' (To Return)

  • I can't wait to go back to Italy someday.
  • He left his wallet at home and had to go back for it.
  • Let's never go back to that restaurant; it was terrible.

Use 2: 'Go back on' (To Break a Promise)

  • Don't go back on your promise.
  • The company went back on its word and didn't give us a raise.
  • He's not a reliable person; he often goes back on his commitments.

84.title: Go down
84.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To decrease in level, price, or amount. It can also mean for a system (like a server) to stop working, or for the sun to set.

Use 1: To Decrease

  • The price of gas has gone down recently.
  • His fever finally went down.
  • Inflation is starting to go down.

Use 2: To Stop Working (Systems)

  • The server went down for maintenance.
  • I can't work; the entire network just went down.

Use 3: For the Sun to Set

  • Let's watch the sun go down over the ocean.
  • It gets cold here after the sun goes down.

85.title: Go off
85.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has three common uses: for an alarm or bomb to activate, for food to spoil, or (UK) to leave a place.

Use 1: To Activate (Alarm, Bomb)

  • The fire alarm went off in the middle of the night.
  • My phone alarm goes off at 6 AM every day.
  • The bomb went off without warning.

Use 2: For Food to Spoil (Go bad)

  • Don't eat that yogurt; it smells like it has gone off.
  • The milk went off because I left it out of the fridge.

Use 3: To Leave (Mainly UK)

  • He went off to work an hour ago.
  • She went off without saying goodbye.

86.title: Go on
86.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to happen, or to continue doing something.

Use 1: To Happen

  • What's going on here? Why is everyone shouting?
  • There's a big event going on downtown.
  • I had no idea what was going on.

Use 2: To Continue

  • I can't believe he just went on talking as if nothing happened.
  • Please go on with your story.
  • The show must go on.
  • She went on to become a famous lawyer.

87.title: Go over
87.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To review, check, or examine something carefully, often step-by-step.

Examples:

  • Let's go over the plan one more time.
  • You should go over your notes before the test.
  • The manager wants to go over the sales figures with me.
  • We went over the presentation slides to check for errors.
  • Can we go over the details of the contract?
  • I went over my essay and found several typos.

88.title: Go through
88.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to experience a difficult or unpleasant situation, or to examine a set of items carefully.

Use 1: To Experience (Hardship)

  • She has gone through a lot this year with her illness.
  • You can't imagine what he went through during the war.
  • The company is going through a difficult period.

Use 2: To Examine or Search

  • We have to go through a lot of bureaucracy to get anything approved.
  • I went through my emails looking for the file.
  • Security goes through everyone's bags at the entrance.

89.title: Grow up
89.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To develop from a child into an adult. It is also used as a command to tell someone to stop acting immaturely.

Use 1: To Become an Adult

  • When I grow up, I want to be a firefighter.
  • She grew up in a small town in the countryside.
  • Where did you grow up?
  • My children are growing up so fast.

Use 2: To Tell Someone to Be Mature (Command)

  • He's 30 but still acts like a child. I wish he would grow up.
  • Stop complaining and grow up!

90.title: Hand down
90.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To give or pass something (like knowledge, traditions, or possessions) to a younger generation or successor.

Examples:

  • This tradition has been handed down through generations.
  • The watch was handed down to me from my grandfather.
  • These stories were handed down orally.
  • I wore my brother's hand-me-down (noun) clothes as a kid.
  • The skills of the craft are handed down from master to apprentice.
  • The court is expected to hand down its decision tomorrow.

91.title: Hand in
91.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To submit or give something (like homework, a report, or a resignation) to a person in authority.

Examples:

  • You must hand in your essay by Friday.
  • I handed in my resignation yesterday.
  • Please hand in your keys when you check out.
  • Have you handed in your homework yet?
  • The police asked the man to hand in his weapon.
  • All reports must be handed in by 5 PM.

92.title: Hand out
92.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To distribute or give things to each member of a group.

Examples:

  • The teacher handed out the worksheets to the students.
  • They were handing out flyers on the street.
  • Can you help me hand out the drinks?
  • The organization hands out food to people in need.
  • He was handing out advice to everyone.
  • Please wait until all the papers are handed out.

93.title: Hand over
93.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To give something (especially control, power, or a responsibility) to someone else.

Examples:

  • The CEO will hand over the company to her successor next year.
  • The captured soldier was forced to hand over his weapon.
  • The thief told the cashier to hand over the money.
  • When I leave, I'll need to hand over my projects to a colleague.
  • The formal handover (noun) of power will be next week.
  • She handed over the documents to the police.

94.title: Hang out
94.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

An informal verb meaning to spend time relaxing or socializing casually with friends.

Examples:

  • On weekends, we like to hang out at the park or the mall.
  • He's going to hang out with his friends after school.
  • Where do the local kids usually hang out?
  • I'm just hanging out at home tonight.
  • Do you want to hang out later?
  • This cafe is a popular hangout (noun) for students.

95.title: Hinge on
95.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To depend entirely on a single factor, event, or condition. The outcome is determined by this one thing.

Examples:

  • The success of the project hinges on getting the new funding.
  • The game will hinge on what the referee decides.
  • His whole future hinges on this one exam.
  • The case hinges on the testimony of a single witness.
  • Everything hinges on his decision.
  • Our vacation plans hinge on whether I can get time off work.

96.title: Hold on
96.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has three common uses: to wait for a short time, to grip something tightly, or to tell someone to stop.

Use 1: To Wait (Often on the Phone)

  • Please hold on a moment while I check your file.
  • Hold on, I'll be right back.
  • Can you hold on? I need to get a pen.

Use 2: To Grip Tightly

  • Hold on to the railing so you don't fall.
  • She held on to my hand tightly.
  • Hold on! We're going over a bump.

Use 3: To Stop or Wait (Command)

  • Hold on! You're driving too fast.
  • Hold on, I don't think that's the right answer.

97.title: Iron out
97.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To solve or resolve small problems, difficulties, or details in a plan or agreement.

Examples:

  • We still need to iron out a few details before the launch.
  • The two sides met to iron out their differences.
  • The team is working to iron out the bugs in the software.
  • Let's iron out the final schedule for the event.
  • They managed to iron out a new contract.
  • Once we iron out these minor issues, we'll be ready.

98.title: Join in
98.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To participate or become involved in an activity that a group of people are already doing.

Examples:

  • We're playing a game, would you like to join in?
  • Everyone started singing, so we decided to join in.
  • Don't be shy, join in the conversation!
  • The kids invited the new student to join in their game.
  • She joined in the celebration after the team won.
  • We'd be happy for you to join in.

99.title: Keep away
99.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To prevent someone or something from going near a particular place, person, or thing. Often used as a warning.

Examples:

  • Keep away from the edge of the cliff.
  • You must keep the chemicals away from children.
  • The fence is to keep predators away.
  • I'm trying to keep away from sugary snacks.
  • Keep that dog away from me!
  • The smoke helped to keep the mosquitos away.

100.title: Keep going
100.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To continue moving or doing something without stopping, often in the face of difficulty. It is a common phrase of encouragement.

Examples:

  • The race is tough, but you have to keep going.
  • Even when things get difficult, just keep going.
  • I know you're tired, but keep going! You're almost at the finish line.
  • She kept going even after she fell.
  • We can't stop here; we have to keep going.
  • He kept going until he reached his goal.

101.title: Keep on
101.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To continue doing something, often persistently or despite difficulty. It strongly emphasizes the continuation.

Examples:

  • Don't stop now, keep on trying!
  • I told him to be quiet, but he just kept on talking.
  • We have to keep on working until the project is finished.
  • No matter what happens, you must keep on fighting.
  • Why do you keep on asking the same question?
  • The machine kept on making a strange noise.

102.title: Kick off
102.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (also Noun 'kick-off')

To formally start an event, meeting, project, or game.

Use 1: To Start a Meeting or Project

  • We will kick off the new project with a team meeting on Monday.
  • The CEO will kick off the conference with a speech.
  • Let's kick off this discussion with a review of the data.

Use 2: To Start a Game (especially football)

  • The game is scheduled to kick off at 8 PM.
  • What time is the kick-off (noun)?
  • The festival kicks off with a parade.

103.title: Lay out
103.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to explain or present something clearly, or to arrange or design something physically.

Use 1: To Explain or Present Clearly

  • Can you lay out the pros and cons of this approach?
  • The manager laid out her expectations for the team.
  • The document lays out the full details of the plan.

Use 2: To Arrange or Design

  • She laid out her clothes on the bed for the next day.
  • The architect laid out the design for the new office.
  • I like the layout (noun) of this apartment.

104.title: Leave out
104.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to omit or not include something, or to exclude someone socially. 'Left out' is the past form.

Use 1: To Omit (by accident or intentionally)

  • You filled out the form, but you left out the last question.
  • Don't leave out any important details in your report.
  • I think we left out a key ingredient.

Use 2: To Exclude Socially

  • He felt left out when his friends went to the movies without him.
  • She was left out of the party invitations.
  • No one likes to feel left out.

105.title: Let down
105.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (also Noun 'letdown')

To disappoint someone by failing to do what they expected or by not providing the help or support they needed.

Examples:

  • He promised he would help, but he let me down.
  • I'm counting on you, so please don't let me down.
  • The team felt they let down their fans after losing the game.
  • The movie was a real letdown (noun); I expected it to be much better.
  • She felt let down by the company's decision.
  • You can always rely on her; she will never let you down.

106.title: Let in
106.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To allow someone or something to enter a place.

Examples:

  • Could you open the door and let the cat in?
  • They won't let you in without a ticket.
  • Open the window and let in some fresh air.
  • The security guard let him in after checking his ID.
  • The hole in the roof is letting in water.
  • Don't let in any strangers.

107.title: Log in / Log into
107.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To gain access to a computer system, website, or account by entering your credentials (like a username and password). A synonym for 'log on'.

Examples:

  • First, log in with your username and password.
  • I can't log into my email account.
  • You must log in to see your profile.
  • What's your login (noun) information?
  • The system automatically logs you in.
  • I forgot my password and can't log in.

108.title: Log on / Log onto
108.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To gain access to a computer system, network, or website. A common synonym for 'log in'.

Examples:

  • I can't log on to my email account.
  • Please log on to the network to access the shared files.
  • She logged on and checked her messages.
  • Millions of users log on to the platform every day.
  • You will need a password to log on.
  • He logged onto the main server.

109.title: Look after
109.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To take care of or be responsible for someone or something (like a child, pet, patient, or property).

Examples:

  • Can you look after the kids for a couple of hours?
  • Who is going to look after your plants while you're away?
  • The nurse looks after the patients on this ward.
  • He needs someone to look after his elderly father.
  • It's important to look after your health.
  • Please look after my suitcase for a minute.

110.title: Look around
110.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To explore or casually inspect a place, or to turn your head to see what is around you.

Examples:

  • When we arrived at the hotel, we started to look around the neighborhood.
  • She spent the afternoon looking around the shops.
  • We have 30 minutes to look around the museum.
  • (In a shop) 'Can I help you?' 'No, thanks, I'm just looking around.'
  • He looked around the room, but he didn't see her.
  • Let's look around and see if we can find a good place to eat.

111.title: Look down on
111.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (3-word)

To think that you are better or more important than someone else; to regard someone with contempt or superiority.

Examples:

  • You should never look down on someone just because they have less money.
  • She looks down on her colleagues because she has a higher degree.
  • It's wrong to look down on people who do manual labor.
  • He felt that his wealthy in-laws looked down on him.
  • I hate the way he looks down on everyone.
  • Just because you're successful doesn't mean you can look down on others.

112.title: Look for
112.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To search for someone or something; to try to find.

Examples:

  • I'm looking for my keys; have you seen them?
  • She's looking for a new job.
  • What are you looking for in this drawer?
  • We are looking for a solution to this problem.
  • He went to the kitchen to look for a snack.
  • The police are looking for the missing child.

113.title: Look forward to
113.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (3-word)

To feel happy and excited about a future event.
Grammar Rule: The 'to' in this phrase is a preposition, so it must be followed by a noun or a gerund (-ing verb).

Examples:

  • I'm really looking forward to our vacation next month.
  • She's looking forward to her birthday.
  • (Correct) I look forward to hearing from you soon.
  • (Incorrect) ~I look forward to hear from you.~
  • (Correct) We are looking forward to meeting the new team.
  • (Incorrect) ~We are looking forward to meet...~
  • He wasn't looking forward to the exam.

114.title: Look into
114.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To investigate, explore, or examine the facts about a problem, situation, or possibility.

Examples:

  • The police are looking into the cause of the accident.
  • I don't know the answer, but I will look into it for you.
  • We need to look into why this error keeps happening.
  • The company is looking into the possibility of expanding overseas.
  • Thank you for the complaint; we will look into this matter immediately.
  • She looked into several different colleges before choosing one.

115.title: Look like
115.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to resemble someone or something in appearance, or to appear probable or likely.

Use 1: To Resemble (Appearance)

  • You look like your mother.
  • That cloud looks like a dragon.
  • He looks like a famous actor.
  • This looks like a great place to camp.

Use 2: To Seem Probable

  • It looks like it's going to rain.
  • It looks like we're going to be late.
  • It looks like the project will be a success.

116.title: Look over
116.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To review or examine something quickly, often to check for errors. A synonym for 'read over'.

Examples:

  • She quickly looked over the report before the meeting.
  • Can you look over my email before I send it?
  • I'll look over the contract tonight.
  • He looked over his notes one last time before the exam.
  • The editor looked over the article for typos.
  • I just need five minutes to look this over.

117.title: Look up
117.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to find a piece of information in a reference source, or for a situation to improve.

Use 1: To Find Information

  • If you don't know the word, look it up in the dictionary.
  • I'll look up his phone number online.
  • Can you look up the opening times for the museum?
  • I had to look up the capital of Ecuador.

Use 2: For a Situation to Improve

  • Things are finally looking up for them after a tough year.
  • My job prospects are looking up.
  • Sales were bad, but they are starting to look up.

118.title: Look up to
118.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (3-word)

To admire and respect someone, often someone older or in a position of authority. It is the opposite of 'look down on'.

Examples:

  • I've always looked up to my older sister.
  • He's a role model that many young players look up to.
  • She was a leader that everyone looked up to.
  • It's important to have someone you can look up to.
  • He really looks up to his grandfather.
  • I look up to her for her courage and determination.

119.title: Make ends meet
119.content:
Grammatical Type: Idiomatic Expression

To have just enough money to pay for your basic living expenses (like food, rent, and bills).

Examples:

  • She works two jobs to make ends meet.
  • With rising prices, it's becoming harder to make ends meet.
  • We have to budget carefully to make ends meet.
  • They were struggling to make ends meet on one salary.
  • After he lost his job, they found it impossible to make ends meet.
  • How do you make ends meet with such a low income?

120.title: Make out
120.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has multiple uses: to see or hear something with difficulty, (informal) to kiss passionately, or to write a check.

Use 1: To See/Hear with Difficulty

  • I can't make out what he's saying.
  • It was so foggy, I could just make out a figure in the distance.
  • Can you make out the signature on this document?

Use 2: To Kiss Passionately (Informal)

  • I saw them making out at the party.
  • They were making out in the back of the car.

Use 3: To Write a Check

  • Who should I make the check out to?
  • Please make it out to 'SmartDeck Inc.'.

121.title: Make sense
121.content:
Grammatical Type: Idiomatic Expression

To be logical, understandable, or practical.

Examples:

  • His explanation didn't make sense at all. I'm still confused.
  • Now that you explain it that way, it starts to make sense.
  • Does that make sense to you?
  • It makes sense to save money for an emergency.
  • This paragraph doesn't make sense; it's full of errors.
  • What he is proposing simply does not make sense.

122.title: Make up
122.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (also Noun 'makeup')

A very common phrasal verb with many uses, including: to invent a story, to reconcile, to form a whole, or to apply cosmetics.

Use 1: To Invent a Story or Excuse

  • He made up an excuse for being late.
  • Children often make up imaginary friends.
  • I don't believe you; I think you made up that whole story.

Use 2: To Reconcile (After an Argument)

  • They had an argument, but they made up an hour later.
  • After the argument, it's hard for them to make up.
  • Let's stop fighting and make up.

Use 3: To Form or Constitute a Whole

  • Women make up 50% of the workforce.
  • This class is made up of students from ten different countries.

Use 4: To Apply Cosmetics

  • She is in the bathroom making up her face.
  • He wears makeup (noun) for his role on stage.

123.title: Make up for
123.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (3-word)

To compensate for something bad, lacking, or a mistake; to do something good to balance a negative situation.

Examples:

  • She was late, but she made up for it by staying late to finish the work.
  • His enthusiasm helps to make up for his lack of experience.
  • I'm sorry I missed your birthday. How can I make it up for you?
  • He bought her flowers to make up for forgetting their anniversary.
  • The beautiful weather made up for the terrible hotel.
  • I need to study hard to make up for lost time.

124.title: Make off
124.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To escape, especially quickly and with something that has been stolen. Almost always used with 'with'.

Examples:

  • The thieves made off with thousands of dollars in jewelry.
  • A raccoon made off with our picnic basket!
  • The burglars made off before the police arrived.
  • He grabbed the wallet and made off down the street.
  • The teenagers made off with a stolen car.
  • She made off with his pen when he wasn't looking.

125.title: Mess around
125.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to behave in a silly or unserious way (waste time), or to handle something carelessly or dangerously.

Use 1: To Waste Time or Behave Silly

  • Stop messing around and do your homework!
  • We just messed around all afternoon, listening to music.
  • He's always messing around in class instead of working.

Use 2: To Handle Dangerously or Carelessly

  • Don't mess around with the electrical wires; it's dangerous.
  • I told you not to mess around with my camera.
  • He's messing around with things he doesn't understand.

126.title: Off (Adverb Particle / Adjective)
126.content:
Grammatical Type: Adverb Particle / Adjective

'Off' is not a phrasal verb by itself, but it's a key component. It can mean that food is spoiled, or (as a particle) indicate leaving or removal (e.g., 'turn off', 'set off').

Use 1: Spoiled (Adjective)

  • This milk smells like it's off; we should throw it away.
  • I think this meat has gone off.

Use 2: Leaving (Adverb)

  • Well, I'm off to bed now. Good night!
  • She's off on vacation for two weeks.

Use 3: In Phrasal Verbs (Particle)

  • Please turn off the lights.
  • They called off the meeting. (Cancel)
  • He set off the alarm. (Trigger)

127.title: Over (Adverb Particle / Preposition)
127.content:
Grammatical Type: Adverb Particle / Preposition

'Over' is not a phrasal verb by itself. As an adverb, it most commonly means 'finished' or 'ended'. As a particle, it's used in many phrasal verbs (e.g., 'go over', 'look over').

Use 1: Finished or Ended (Adverb)

  • Call me when the movie is over.
  • The game is over, and our team lost.
  • Summer is almost over.
  • Thank goodness that meeting is over.

Use 2: In Phrasal Verbs (Particle)

  • Let's go over the plan. (Review)
  • Can you look over this report? (Examine)
  • He handed over the documents. (Surrender)

128.title: Pay back
128.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to return money that you borrowed, or to return a favor or get revenge on someone.

Use 1: To Return Money

  • I lent him money a month ago, and he still hasn't paid me back.
  • I'll pay you back on Friday.
  • You need to pay back your loan.

Use 2: To Return a Favor or Get Revenge

  • She helped me, and I'll pay her back one day. (Favor)
  • He insulted me, and I'm going to pay him back. (Revenge)
  • Thanks for your help, I'll pay you back.

129.title: Pay off
129.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (also Noun 'payoff')

Has two main uses: for an action to be successful and bring good results, or to finish paying a debt in full.

Use 1: To Be Successful (Bring results)

  • All his hard work finally paid off.
  • I studied for weeks, and it paid off; I got an A.
  • Taking that risk really paid off.
  • The payoff (noun) was huge.

Use 2: To Finish Paying a Debt

  • I need to pay off my student loans in the next few years.
  • We finally paid off our mortgage.
  • He used his bonus to pay off his credit card debt.

130.title: Phase out
130.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To gradually stop using, remove, or discontinue something in stages.

Examples:

  • We will phase out the old version of the software by the end of the year.
  • The government plans to phase out plastic bags.
  • The company is phasing out the use of old computers.
  • Incandescent light bulbs are being phased out.
  • The 'phase-out' (noun) process will take six months.
  • They are phasing the old model out.

131.title: Pick up
131.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

A very common phrasal verb with many uses, including: to collect someone, to learn a skill, to lift an object, or to answer a phone.

Use 1: To Collect Someone (in a vehicle)

  • I'll pick you up from the airport at 8 PM.
  • What time should I pick up the kids from school?

Use 2: To Learn a Skill (casually)

  • She picked up Spanish very quickly while living in Madrid.
  • I picked up a few bad habits from my old job.

Use 3: To Lift an Object

  • He picked up the book from the floor.
  • Please pick up your trash.

Use 4: To Answer a Phone

  • I'm calling him, but he won't pick up.
  • Please pick up the phone!

132.title: Play down
132.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To try to make something seem less important, serious, or impressive than it really is. The opposite of 'play up' or 'exaggerate'.

Examples:

  • The government tried to play down the scandal, but the media found out.
  • He always plays down his achievements; he's very modest.
  • The team played down their chances of winning the championship.
  • The company played down the negative side effects of the drug.
  • She played down the seriousness of her injury.
  • Don't play down your role in this project; you were essential.

133.title: Press on
133.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To continue doing something in a determined way, often despite difficulties or interruptions.

Examples:

  • Don't stop working. You need to press on if you want to meet the deadline.
  • Despite the bad weather, the hikers decided to press on.
  • We must press on with the reforms, even if they are unpopular.
  • The team lost the first game, but they pressed on and won the tournament.
  • She was tired, but she pressed on to finish the marathon.
  • Let's press on; we only have a few more miles to go.

134.title: Pull out
134.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to withdraw from an activity, commitment, or competition, or (for a vehicle) to move out into traffic.

Use 1: To Withdraw (from a deal, race, etc.)

  • After the scandal, the politician was forced to pull out of the race.
  • The main investor pulled out of the deal at the last minute.
  • She had to pull out of the competition due to an injury.

Use 2: To Move into Traffic (Vehicle)

  • A car pulled out right in front of me, and I had to brake.
  • Be careful when you pull out of the driveway.
  • The bus pulled out into the fast lane.

135.title: Push back
135.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (also Noun 'pushback')

To delay or postpone a planned event or deadline to a later time or date.

Examples:

  • We have to push back the deadline by one week.
  • Due to unexpected delays, they decided to push back the product launch.
  • Can we push the meeting back to 3 PM?
  • The release date was pushed back by a month.
  • We got a lot of pushback (noun) on that idea.
  • Don't let them push back the timeline any further.

136.title: Put away
136.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To put something in its correct storage place (where it belongs), often after using it.

Examples:

  • Please put away your toys when you're done playing.
  • He never puts away the milk after he uses it.
  • I need to put away the clean laundry.
  • Put away your phone and listen to me.
  • She put the dishes away in the cupboard.
  • It's time to put away the winter clothes.

137.title: Put down
137.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has three main uses: to place an object onto a surface, to criticize or insult someone, or to euthanize an animal.

Use 1: To Place an Object Down

  • She put down her phone to listen to me.
  • He put down the heavy box.
  • Put that down! It's fragile.

Use 2: To Criticize or Insult

  • He's always putting down his colleagues.
  • It was a mean put-down (noun).
  • Why do you always put me down in front of our friends?

Use 3: To Euthanize an Animal

  • Our old cat was very sick, so we had to put her down.
  • It's a difficult decision to put an animal down.

138.title: Put off
138.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to postpone or delay an event, or to make someone feel dislike or disinterest (discourage).

Use 1: To Postpone or Delay

  • They had to put off the meeting until next week.
  • Never put off until tomorrow what you can do today.
  • I keep putting off going to the dentist.
  • Don't put it off any longer.

Use 2: To Discourage or Repel

  • His bad attitude really put me off.
  • The smell of the food completely put him off.
  • I was put off by his arrogance.

139.title: Put on
139.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has three common uses: to place clothes or accessories on your body, to gain weight, or to organize/stage an event.

Use 1: To Wear Clothes/Accessories

  • It's cold outside; you should put on a jacket.
  • He put on his glasses and started to read.
  • Wait, I need to put on my shoes.

Use 2: To Gain Weight

  • I think I've put on a few kilos over the holidays.
  • He put on weight after he quit smoking.

Use 3: To Organize or Stage an Event

  • The school is putting on a play next week.
  • They put on a great concert.

140.title: Put up with
140.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (3-word)

To tolerate or accept an unpleasant situation or person's behavior without complaining.

Examples:

  • I don't know how she puts up with his constant complaining.
  • I will not put up with his bad attitude any longer.
  • We had to put up with the construction noise for months.
  • I can't put up with this toothache anymore.
  • Why do you put up with him?
  • He's difficult, but his boss puts up with him because he's a great designer.

141.title: Ramp up
141.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To increase the level, speed, or amount of something significantly and quickly (e.g., production, effort, intensity).

Examples:

  • We need to ramp up production to meet the holiday season demand.
  • The company is ramping up its marketing efforts.
  • They ramped up the pressure on the government.
  • The 'ramp-up' (noun) period for new employees is two weeks.
  • The search party ramped up their efforts as night approached.
  • We need to ramp up for the product launch.

142.title: Run into
142.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has three main uses: to meet someone unexpectedly, to encounter a problem, or to collide with something. 'Ran into' is the simple past.

Use 1: To Meet by Chance

  • I ran into an old friend at the supermarket yesterday.
  • Guess who I ran into today?
  • It's always nice running into you.

Use 2: To Encounter a Problem

  • We ran into a problem with the server.
  • I ran into some trouble while installing the software.
  • If you run into any issues, let me know.

Use 3: To Collide With

  • He wasn't looking and ran into a tree.
  • The car slid on the ice and ran into a fence.

143.title: Read over
143.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To read something quickly from beginning to end, usually to check for errors or to get a general idea. A synonym for 'look over'.

Examples:

  • Could you read over this email for me to check for errors?
  • He quickly read over the contract before signing it.
  • I'm going to read over my notes one more time.
  • Please read over your answers before you hand in the test.
  • She read the document over.
  • I need a few minutes to read this over.

144.title: Roll out
144.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (also Noun 'rollout')

To officially launch or introduce a new product, service, system, or policy, often in stages.

Examples:

  • We plan to roll out the new software update in the third quarter.
  • The company will roll out the new policy next month.
  • The government is rolling out a new vaccination program.
  • The 'rollout' (noun) will begin in Europe and then move to Asia.
  • When will they roll out the new features?
  • The new system was rolled out to all departments.

145.title: Rule out
145.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To exclude, eliminate, or decide that something is not a possibility.

Examples:

  • Based on the evidence, we can rule out the possibility of an accident.
  • The doctor did some tests to rule out any serious conditions.
