  • We can't rule out that he was lying.
  • The police have not ruled out sabotage.
  • I wouldn't rule out applying for that job.
  • This result rules out our main hypothesis.

146.title: Run out
146.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To be completely used or finished (intransitive). This focuses on the supply itself (especially time, patience, or contracts) reaching zero.

Examples:

  • Hurry up! We're running out of time. (Note: Here, 'time' is the object of 'of', see next modal).
  • Hurry up! The time is running out.
  • My patience is running out.
  • Our contract runs out at the end of the year.
  • The milk has run out. (Compare to: We have run out *of* milk).
  • The luck will run out eventually.
  • The printer ink ran out.

147.title: Run out of
147.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (3-word)

To use the entire supply of a specific thing (transitive). This focuses on the person who no longer has the item.

Examples:

  • We ran out of milk, so I need to go to the store.
  • I think we're running out of gas; we should stop at the next station.
  • I've run out of ideas.
  • She ran out of money before the end of the month.
  • The printer ran out of ink.
  • What will you do if you run out of options?

148.title: Scale up
148.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To increase the size, amount, or scale of something, especially a business, operation, or production. The opposite of 'scale down'.

Examples:

  • Our goal is to scale up our operations to serve international markets.
  • The application was designed to scale up easily as the number of users grows.
  • We need to scale up our efforts if we want to succeed.
  • The company is scaling up production.
  • Scaling up a small business is very challenging.
  • This is a good prototype, but can we scale it up?

149.title: Set off
149.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to start a journey, or to trigger or cause an alarm, bomb, or event to begin.

Use 1: To Start a Journey

  • We set off for the beach early in the morning.
  • What time do we need to set off tomorrow?
  • They set off on their hike just after dawn.

Use 2: To Trigger or Cause (Alarm, Event)

  • The smoke from the toast set off the fire alarm.
  • The loud noise set off a panic in the crowd.
  • The bomb was set off remotely.

150.title: Set up
150.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (also Noun 'setup')

A very common phrasal verb with many uses, including: to assemble/install, to organize/arrange, or to frame/trick someone.

Use 1: To Assemble or Install (Equipment)

  • Can you help me set up my new computer?
  • It took two hours to set up the tent.
  • The 'setup' (noun) process is very simple.

Use 2: To Organize or Arrange (Business, Meeting)

  • He set up his own company five years ago.
  • Let's set up a meeting for next week.
  • We set up a committee to investigate the problem.

Use 3: To Frame or Trick Someone

  • He claimed he was innocent and had been set up.
  • The police set up a trap for the criminals.

151.title: Settle down
151.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to become calm, quiet, or comfortable, or to adopt a more stable and permanent lifestyle (e.g., buy a house, start a family).

Use 1: To Become Calm or Quiet

  • The teacher told the excited children to settle down and listen.
  • Please settle down so we can start the movie.
  • After the excitement, it took a while for the crowd to settle down.

Use 2: To Adopt a Stable Lifestyle

  • After traveling for years, they decided to settle down and buy a house.
  • He doesn't feel ready to settle down and start a family yet.
  • They settled down in a quiet suburb.

152.title: Shine through
152.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Used when a positive quality (like talent, personality, or kindness) is very evident or easily seen, especially despite a difficult situation or shyness.

Examples:

  • She's very shy, but her talent really shines through on stage.
  • His kindness shines through in everything he does.
  • Even in difficult times, their optimism shone through. (Past tense: shone)
  • Let your natural enthusiasm shine through in the interview.
  • His intelligence shone through in his report.
  • It was a tough performance, but her professionalism shone through.

153.title: Show up
153.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to arrive or appear, especially at a place where you are expected, or (informal) to embarrass someone by being superior ('show someone up').

Use 1: To Arrive or Appear

  • I waited for an hour, but he never showed up.
  • What time did you show up at the party?
  • Only ten people showed up for the meeting.
  • He showed up late, as usual.

Use 2: To Embarrass by Superiority ('show someone up')

  • He's always trying to show up his colleagues in meetings.
  • She didn't want to show up the other singers, so she sang a simple song.
  • Don't show me up in front of my friends!

154.title: Show off
154.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (also Noun 'show-off')

To boastfully or proudly display one's abilities, possessions, or appearance, often in a way that annoys others.

Examples:

  • He's always showing off his expensive car.
  • The kids were showing off their new toys to everyone.
  • Stop showing off and let someone else have a turn.
  • She's just showing off for the new manager.
  • He's such a show-off (noun) on the basketball court.
  • There's no need to show off; we know you're talented.

155.title: Shut down
155.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (also Noun 'shutdown')

Has three main uses: to turn off a machine (like a computer), to close a business permanently, or to reject an idea or stop a person from talking.

Use 1: To Turn Off a Machine

  • Don't forget to shut down your computer before you leave.
  • The factory shuts down the main assembly line at night.

Use 2: To Close a Business

  • The restaurant was shut down for health code violations.
  • The government is facing a potential shutdown (noun).

Use 3: To Reject or Silence

  • She tried to make a suggestion, but her boss shut her down immediately.
  • He completely shuts down and refuses to talk about his feelings.

156.title: Sign off on
156.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (3-word)

To give formal approval or authorization for something by signing or agreeing to it.

Examples:

  • I need you to sign off on these designs by the end of the day.
  • The manager has to sign off on all expenses over $100.
  • We can't launch until the legal team signs off on the terms.
  • Who signed off on this purchase?
  • The board will meet to sign off on the new budget.
  • Once you sign off on the contract, we can begin work.

157.title: Sink in
157.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Used when a piece of information, news (often surprising or negative), or an event is gradually and fully understood or realized.

Examples:

  • It took a while for the new information to sink in.
  • He lost his job, but the reality of it hasn't sunk in yet.
  • I was so shocked, it took a moment for his words to sink in.
  • The scale of the disaster is still sinking in for the residents.
  • I had to read the email three times before the news would sink in.
  • She won the lottery, but it still hasn't sunk in.

158.title: Sit down
158.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To move from a standing position to a seated one. It can be a command or a description.

Examples:

  • Please sit down and make yourself comfortable.
  • We sat down at the table and waited to order.
  • He told the dog to sit down.
  • Let's sit down and have a serious talk.
  • I've been standing all day; I really need to sit down.
  • Sit down, please. The show is about to start.

159.title: Sit out
159.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To not participate in an activity (like a game, a round, or a dance) while others do, often due to injury, illness, or choice.

Examples:

  • He was injured in the first game and had to sit out for the rest of the season.
  • I'm not feeling well; I think I'll sit this one out.
  • My knee hurts, so I'm going to sit out the next game.
  • She decided to sit out the discussion about politics.
  • 'Are you playing cards?' 'No, I'll sit this round out.'
  • I'm tired of dancing; I'm sitting this one out.

160.title: Slow down
160.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to reduce speed (literal, for a vehicle or person), or to become less active or busy (lifestyle).

Use 1: To Reduce Speed

  • You're driving too fast; you need to slow down.
  • Please slow down; I can't keep up with you.
  • The car slowed down as it approached the stop sign.
  • Slow down! There's a 30mph limit here.

Use 2: To Become Less Active or Busy

  • The doctor told him to slow down and work less.
  • Business tends to slow down during the winter months.
  • It's nice to slow down and relax on vacation.

161.title: Sort out
161.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to solve a problem or resolve a complex situation, or to organize or tidy things.

Use 1: To Solve or Resolve a Problem

  • We need to sort out our financial problems.
  • Don't worry, I'll sort out the misunderstanding with the client.
  • They had a big argument, but they finally sorted it out.

Use 2: To Organize or Tidy

  • Let's sort out the attic and get rid of things we don't need.
  • I need to sort out these files alphabetically.
  • Can you sort out the recycling from the trash?

162.title: Spell out
162.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to say or write the letters of a word in order, or to explain something very clearly and in detail.

Use 1: To Explain Clearly and Simply

  • The details of the plan need to be spelled out more clearly.
  • He's so dense, you have to spell everything out for him.
  • Let me spell it out for you: if you're late again, you're fired.

Use 2: To Say/Write Letters in Order

  • 'How do you spell your name?' 'Can you spell that out, please?'
  • He spelled out the password for me.
  • She had to spell out her last name for the receptionist.

163.title: Stand for
163.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has three main uses: for initials/acronyms to represent words, to support a belief or value, or (in negative) to tolerate behavior.

Use 1: To Represent (Acronyms)

  • The initials 'USA' stand for the United States of America.
  • What does 'CPU' stand for?
  • 'PM' can stand for 'Prime Minister' or 'post meridiem'.

Use 2: To Support or Believe In (Values)

  • Our company stands for quality and customer service.
  • He stands for honesty and integrity.
  • It's important to stand for what you believe in.

Use 3: To Tolerate (Negative)

  • I will not stand for this kind of behavior.
  • The teacher won't stand for any cheating.

164.title: Stand out
164.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To be very noticeable, different, or much better than other people or things.

Examples:

  • Her bright red coat made her stand out in the crowd.
  • Among all the applicants, her experience really makes her stand out.
  • If you want to get the job, you need to find a way to stand out.
  • The white house stands out among all the gray buildings.
  • His performance stood out as the best of the night.
  • What makes this product stand out from the competition?

165.title: Stand up
165.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has three main uses: the literal action of rising to your feet, to defend someone/something, or (informal) to fail to meet someone for a date.

Use 1: To Rise to Your Feet

  • Everyone, please stand up for the national anthem.
  • He stood up to let the elderly woman sit down.
  • Please stand up when your name is called.

Use 2: To Defend ('stand up for/to')

  • You need to stand up for what you believe in.
  • She was the only one who stood up to the bully.
  • He always stands up for his friends.

Use 3: To Fail to Keep a Date ('stand someone up')

  • I can't believe he stood me up! I waited for an hour.
  • She was stood up on her prom night.

166.title: Stay in
166.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To remain at home; to not go out, especially for social reasons. It is the opposite of 'go out' or 'eat out'.

Examples:

  • Let's stay in and watch a movie instead of going to the party.
  • I'm feeling tired; I think I'll just stay in tonight.
  • We've been going out a lot. I'd rather stay in this weekend.
  • Staying in is the new going out.
  • It's raining, so let's stay in and play board games.
  • She stayed in all weekend to study for her exam.

167.title: Stay up
167.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To remain awake; to not go to bed, often later than your usual bedtime.

Examples:

  • I had to stay up late to finish my homework.
  • The kids wanted to stay up to watch the fireworks.
  • I can't stay up too late tonight; I have an early meeting.
  • How late did you stay up last night?
  • We stayed up all night talking.
  • Don't stay up waiting for me; I'll be home late.

168.title: Stick around
168.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

An informal verb meaning to stay in a place for a period of time; to wait or remain.

Examples:

  • Why don't you stick around for a while after the party?
  • We're going to stick around for a bit to see if he shows up.
  • He's not the kind of person to stick around when there's trouble.
  • Most of the crowd left, but a few people stuck around.
  • 'Are you leaving?' 'No, I'll stick around.'
  • He stuck around the same company for 20 years.

169.title: Stir up
169.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To cause trouble, arguments, or unpleasant feelings (like anger or fear); to provoke a reaction.

Examples:

  • He's always trying to stir up trouble between his coworkers.
  • The article was intended to stir up controversy.
  • Don't stir up his anger by mentioning the past.
  • The speech stirred up a lot of old memories.
  • He likes stirring up arguments.
  • The politician's comments stirred up resentment.

170.title: Succeed in
170.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To achieve a desired goal or result.
Grammar Rule: It must be followed by a noun or a gerund (-ing verb).

Examples:

  • She finally succeeded in getting the promotion she wanted.
  • After many attempts, he succeeded in solving the puzzle.
  • Did you succeed in convincing him?
  • (Correct) They succeeded in their mission.
  • (Incorrect) ~They succeeded to do their mission.~
  • He succeeded in business at a young age.
  • I hope you succeed in finding what you're looking for.

171.title: Take after
171.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To resemble an older family member in appearance, behavior, or character. This phrasal verb cannot be separated.

Examples:

  • He really takes after his father; they have the same laugh.
  • Everyone says I take after my grandfather.
  • She takes after her mother's side of the family.
  • (Correct) Who do you take after most?
  • (Incorrect) ~Who do you take your mother after?~
  • He's stubborn, just like his dad. He takes after him in that way.
  • I hope the baby takes after you.

172.title: Take away
172.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (also Noun 'takeaway')

Has multiple uses: to remove something, to get food from a restaurant (UK English), or a main point/lesson from a discussion.

Use 1: To Remove Something

  • The waiter came to take away our empty plates.
  • Please take away all this trash.
  • The police took the man away.

Use 2: Food to Go (Mainly UK)

  • Are you eating in or taking away?
  • Let's get a Chinese takeaway (noun) tonight. (Synonym for US 'takeout').

Use 3: A Main Point or Lesson ('takeaway')

  • The main takeaway (noun) from the meeting is that we need to cut costs.
  • What was your key takeaway from the presentation?

173.title: Take care of
173.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (3-word)

Has two main uses: to look after someone/something (synonym of 'look after'), or to handle or be responsible for a task.

Use 1: To Look After (Care)

  • Can you take care of the children while I'm out?
  • You need to take care of your health.
  • Who will take care of your dog?

Use 2: To Handle or Manage (Task)

  • Don't worry about the report; I'll take care of it.
  • Can you take care of booking the flights?
  • The problem has been taken care of.

174.title: Take off
174.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

A very common phrasal verb with many uses, including: an aircraft leaving the ground, removing clothing, becoming suddenly successful, or taking a break from work.

Use 1: To Leave the Ground (Aircraft)

  • The plane is scheduled to take off at 8:00 AM.
  • What time is take-off (noun)?

Use 2: To Remove Clothing

  • Please take off your shoes before entering the house.
  • He took off his wet coat.

Use 3: To Become Successful Rapidly

  • Her career really took off after she won the award.
  • The new app took off and got a million downloads.

Use 4: To Take a Break (from work)

  • I'm going to take a few days off next week.
  • He took the afternoon off to go to the doctor.

175.title: Take out
175.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (also Noun 'takeout')

Has multiple uses, including: removing something, getting food from a restaurant, or obtaining an official document (like a loan).

Use 1: To Remove Something

  • It's your turn to take out the trash.
  • He took his wallet out of his pocket.

Use 2: Food To Go (Mainly US)

  • Let's get some Chinese food to take out tonight.
  • Is that for here or to take out?
  • We ordered takeout (noun).

Use 3: To Obtain (Loan, Insurance)

  • We need to take out a loan to buy the car.
  • She took out a new insurance policy.

Use 4: To Take Someone on a Date

  • He's taking his girlfriend out for dinner.
  • I'd like to take you out sometime.

176.title: Talk over
176.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To discuss a problem or situation thoroughly with someone before making a decision.

Examples:

  • We need to talk over this problem together.
  • Before you decide, talk it over with your family.
  • Let's talk this over at the meeting tomorrow.
  • They spent the evening talking over their options.
  • I'm not sure what to do; I need to talk it over with my wife.
  • Can we talk over the details of the contract?

177.title: Think about
177.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To consider something, especially when making a decision, or to have something or someone on your mind.

Use 1: To Consider (a decision)

  • I need some time to think about your offer.
  • We are thinking about moving to a new city.
  • Have you thought about what you're going to say?

Use 2: To Have on Your Mind

  • I'm thinking about my vacation.
  • What are you thinking about? You look serious.
  • She's always thinking about her kids.

178.title: Think of
178.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Used to ask for an opinion, to have an idea or memory come to your mind, or to consider someone in a particular way.

Use 1: To Ask for an Opinion

  • What do you think of this idea?
  • What did you think of the movie?

Use 2: To Have an Idea/Memory Appear

  • I can't think of his name right now.
  • Can you think of a better way to do this?
  • I just thought of a great solution.

Use 3: To Consider Someone

  • You must think of your family's future.
  • That was very kind of you to think of me.

179.title: Think over
179.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To consider a problem or decision carefully and thoroughly, often taking time before deciding. It implies more careful consideration than 'think about'.

Examples:

  • It's a big decision; you should think it over carefully.
  • I need some time to think over your proposal.
  • He thought over her words for several days.
  • Don't give me an answer now; think it over.
  • Let's think over all the possibilities.
  • She decided to think it over during the weekend.

180.title: Touch base
180.content:
Grammatical Type: Idiomatic Expression

A business/social idiom meaning to make brief contact with someone, usually to get an update, share information, or maintain a connection.

Examples:

  • I just wanted to touch base and see how the project is progressing.
  • Let's touch base after the meeting to discuss the results.
  • I'll touch base with you next week.
  • He's out of the office, but I'll touch base with him tomorrow.
  • It's important to touch base with the team regularly.
  • Can we touch base for a few minutes this afternoon?

181.title: Try on
181.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To put on an item of clothing to see if it fits, suits you, or looks good.

Examples:

  • I'm going to the fitting room to try on these jeans.
  • Can I try this shirt on in a larger size?
  • You should always try on shoes before you buy them.
  • He tried on three different suits for the wedding.
  • 'Do you like this dress?' 'I don't know, try it on.'
  • Where is the fitting room? I'd like to try this on.

182.title: Turn around
182.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to physically rotate or change direction, or to change a situation from bad to good.

Use 1: To Change Direction (Literal)

  • We had to turn around because we forgot the tickets.
  • Turn around slowly and don't make any sudden moves.
  • The car turned around and went back the way it came.

Use 2: To Make Successful (Figurative)

  • The new CEO completely turned the company around.
  • They managed to turn around a losing game.
  • The business was failing, but he turned it around.

183.title: Turn back
183.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To stop a journey and return to where you started, often because of a problem. It also means to stop making progress.

Examples:

  • The storm is getting worse; we should turn back.
  • It's too late to turn back now; we have to finish what we started.
  • The climbers had to turn back due to heavy snow.
  • We were halfway to the beach when we had to turn back for the keys.
  • There is no turning back.
  • You can't turn back the clock. (Idiom: cannot go back to the past)

184.title: Turn down
184.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to reject or refuse an offer, request, or person, or to decrease the volume or intensity (heat, light).

Use 1: To Reject or Refuse

  • She turned down the job offer because the salary was too low.
  • He asked her to the dance, but she politely turned him down.
  • My application for a loan was turned down.

Use 2: To Decrease Volume or Intensity

  • Can you turn down the music? It's too loud.
  • It's too hot in here; please turn down the heat.
  • Turn the lights down; it's too bright.

185.title: Turn off
185.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to deactivate a machine or light, or (informal) to repel or disgust someone.

Use 1: To Deactivate (Machine, Light)

  • Please turn off the lights when you leave the room.
  • Did you turn off the oven?
  • My phone turned off because the battery died.

Use 2: To Repel or Disgust (Informal)

  • The comedian's offensive joke really turned off the audience.
  • His arrogance is a major turn-off (noun).
  • I was turned off by his bad manners.

186.title: Turn on
186.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to activate a machine or light, or (informal) to attract or excite someone.

Use 1: To Activate (Machine, Light)

  • Could you please turn on the lights?
  • He turned on the TV to watch the news.
  • How do I turn on this computer?

Use 2: To Attract or Excite (Informal)

  • Confidence is a quality that really turns me on.
  • His intelligence is a real turn-on (noun).
  • That kind of music doesn't really turn me on.

187.title: Turn up
187.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to appear unexpectedly (a person or an item), or to increase the volume, heat, or intensity.

Use 1: To Appear Unexpectedly

  • My missing keys turned up in my coat pocket.
  • He finally turned up at the party at midnight, an hour late.
  • Don't worry, the document will turn up eventually.

Use 2: To Increase (Volume, Heat)

  • Can you turn up the music? I love this song.
  • It's cold in here; let's turn up the heat.
  • Turn it up!

188.title: Up to
188.content:
Grammatical Type: Prepositional Phrase / Idiom

This is not a phrasal verb, but an important phrase with multiple meanings: to be the responsibility of, (informal) doing/plotting, or as many as (a limit).

Use 1: To Be the Responsibility of

  • It's up to you to decide where we go for dinner.
  • The final decision is up to the manager.
  • I'll leave it up to you.

Use 2: Doing or Plotting (Informal)

  • What are you up to tonight?
  • The kids are very quiet; I wonder what they're up to.
  • He's up to no good.

Use 3: As Many As (A Limit)

  • The car can hold up to five people.
  • You can earn up to $100 a day.

189.title: Use up
189.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To use the entire supply of something, so that nothing is left.

Examples:

  • The kids used up all the cookies.
  • The long meeting used up all my energy for the day.
  • We used up all the printer paper, so we need to order more.
  • I used up my vacation days for the year.
  • Don't use up all the hot water.
  • The project used up our entire budget.

190.title: Wait for
190.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To stay in one place or delay an action until a particular person or thing arrives or happens.

Examples:

  • I'm waiting for the bus.
  • Please wait for me; I'll be ready in five minutes.
  • She's waiting for an important phone call.
  • We're all waiting for you to start.
  • Don't wait for me; go ahead and eat.
  • They are waiting for the results of the test.

191.title: Watch out / Watch out for
191.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Used as a warning to be careful of immediate danger ('Watch out!'), or to be alert for a potential, specific danger ('Watch out for').

Use 1: Immediate Danger ('Watch out!')

  • Watch out! There's a car coming!
  • Watch out! The floor is wet.
  • He shouted, 'Watch out!' just before the branch fell.

Use 2: Be Alert for... ('Watch out for')

  • You should watch out for pickpockets in crowded areas.
  • Watch out for icy patches on the road.
  • Watch out for that guy; he's not very trustworthy.

192.title: Wear off
192.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To gradually decrease in effect or intensity until it disappears. Often used for medicine, feelings, or novelty.

Examples:

  • The pain medication should wear off after a few hours.
  • The initial excitement of the new job started to wear off.
  • The anesthesia is slowly wearing off.
  • The shock of the news still hasn't worn off.
  • The caffeine from the coffee is beginning to wear off.
  • The novelty of the new toy quickly wore off.

193.title: Wind down
193.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To relax and become calm after a period of activity or stress. It can also mean for an activity to gradually come to an end.

Use 1: To Relax

  • I like to wind down with a good book before bed.
  • After a long week at work, I need the weekend to wind down.
  • What do you do to wind down after work?

Use 2: To Come to an End

  • The party started to wind down around midnight.
  • The conference is winding down now.
  • As the day wound down, we packed up our things.

194.title: Work out
194.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (also Noun 'workout')

A very common phrasal verb with three main uses: to exercise, to be successful or resolve well, or to calculate/find a solution.

Use 1: To Exercise

  • I try to work out at the gym three times a week.
  • She has a great workout (noun) routine.
  • He was working out with weights.

Use 2: To Resolve Successfully

  • Don't worry, everything will work out in the end.
  • Their marriage didn't work out.
  • I hope things work out for you.

Use 3: To Calculate or Solve

  • I can't work out this math problem.
  • We need to work out a plan to reduce costs.
  • Can you work out the total cost?

195.title: Worry about
195.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To feel anxious or unhappy about someone or something; to think about problems or potential problems.

Examples:

  • Don't worry about me; I'll be fine.
  • She's worrying about her upcoming exams.
  • There's no need to worry about it.
  • He worries about money all the time.
  • What are you worrying about?
  • I worry about my parents' health.

196.title: Wrap up
196.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

Has two main uses: to finish or conclude an activity (like a meeting or project), or to wrap a gift or object.

Use 1: To Conclude or Finish

  • Let's wrap up this meeting so we can go to lunch.
  • We need to wrap up the project by Friday.
  • Okay, let's wrap it up. We're out of time.

Use 2: To Cover with Paper (e.g., a gift)

  • I need to wrap up this present before the party.
  • She wrapped up the gift beautifully.
  • Wrap up warm; it's cold outside. (Idiom: wear warm clothes)

197.title: Write down
197.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb

To write something on paper, often to ensure you do not forget it.

Examples:

  • Can you write down your phone number for me?
  • Let me write down that address.
  • He wrote down the instructions so he wouldn't forget.
  • Write this down: we need milk, eggs, and bread.
  • I should write down my ideas before I lose them.
  • The police officer wrote down his statement.

198.title: Zero in on
198.content:
Grammatical Type: Phrasal Verb (3-word)

To focus all your attention on one specific thing; to aim or target something precisely.

Examples:

  • Let's zero in on the main cause of the performance issue.
  • The investigation zeroed in on the prime suspect.
  • The missile zeroed in on its target.
  • We need to zero in on what the customer really wants.
  • She zeroed in on the one mistake in the long report.
  • After much discussion, we zeroed in on a final solution.
